docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor's proposal asking the American Medical Association to endorse refusing care to lawyers involved in medical malpractice cases drew an angry response from colleagues on Sunday at the annual meeting of the association. Many doctors stood up to denounce the resolution in passionate speeches -- even after its sponsor, Dr. J. Chris Hawk, asked that it be withdrawn.
docs.abstract: Many doctors at American Medical Association meeting, Chicago, score proposal by Dr J Chris Hawk that group endorse refusing care to lawyers involved in medical malpractice cases; Hawk withdraws proposal he says was intended to draw attention to rising medical malpractice costs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on May 23 about the minimum salaries of Broadway performers under the Actors' Equity contract misstated the proportion of Equity members who receive medical benefits. Members must work at least 12 weeks under an Equity contract within a 12-month period to qualify. Six percent of the membership currently receives benefits, not all members.
docs.abstract: Correction of May 23 article about minimum salaries of Broadway performers under Actors' Equity contract, which misstated proportion of Equity members who receive medical benefits; members must work at least 12 weeks under Equity contract in 12-month period to qualify; six percent of membership currently receives benefits, not all members (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE if the 2000 presidential election had been held in Canada instead of the United States. Political scientists say Al Gore would have run away with the election; George W. Bush would have won no more than 1 of Canada's 10 provinces, and that would have been Alberta, where oil wealth and a taste for cowboy boots remind Canadians of Texas. The presumed one-sided return says a lot about the differences between Canada and the United States. Canada has been influenced much more by the strong social welfare tradition of Western Europe than the American model. Canadians are generally more supportive of same-sex marriage than Americans; they support national health insurance, multiculturalism and gun control laws. Unlike the periodic closely contested national elections in the United States, Canadians are in general agreement. They're liberals.

headline.main: The Nation: Conforming in Canada; The Blue-State Nation to the North

docs.abstract: Canada is virtually one-party state; Liberal Party has won last three elections easily, dominating national government for last 11 years; party's monopoly on power could be interrupted in next parliamentary election on June 28; series of financial scandals have brought scorn upon Liberal politicians across country; Prime Min Paul Martin has been unable to heal party's wounds after nasty internal struggle forced his predecessor Jean Chretien to step down in Dec; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration said Saturday that it would rescind a federal policy that threatened to cut food stamp benefits for several million low-income elderly and disabled people who save money on their medicines by using the new Medicare drug discount cards. The administration's reversal came two days before President Bush was scheduled to visit Missouri to promote use of the cards, which have received a tepid reaction from many Medicare beneficiaries.

headline.main: Drug Savings Won't Affect Food Stamps

docs.abstract: Bush administration will rescind federal policy announced on March 10 that threatens to cut food stamp benefits for low-income elderly and disabled people who use new Medicare prescription drug discount cards; food stamp program assumes people have more money for food when drug expenses decline; administration may have to allow Medicare beneficiaries to take deduction for medical expenses they do not actually incur (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN this nouveau age of wraps, tofu, and salads with bean sprouts, hamburgers are still king. And drive-in restaurants reminiscent of the 50's and 60's, with carhops -- hold the roller skates, please -- still pepper the New Jersey landscape. ''I wanted to do the roller skate thing,'' said Brett Denafo, the owner of a Stewart's Drive-In restaurant in Northfield, just outside Atlantic City, ''but the insurance was $15,000 a year.''
docs.abstract: Article on drive-in restaurants in New Jersey reminiscent of 1950's and 1960's; rising costs and more stringent health laws have lead to decline, but some older drive-ins found ways to comply and new drive-ins are on the way; Brett Denafo, 26, who has opened Stewart's in Northfield, credits Sonic Drive-In chain based in Oklahoma City with resurrecting drive-in restaurant with carhops; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Governor McGreevey has signed legislation that will provide $78 million in aid for doctors facing steep increases in malpractice insurance premiums. But the bill does not include the provision that insurers and the New Jersey Medical Society wanted most: a cap on pain and suffering jury awards for medical malpractice victims. The new law establishes a three-year subsidy fund of $26.1 million annually to defray the cost of medical malpractice insurance for health care providers. The fund will be paid for by a $75 annual fee on doctors, chiropractors, dentists, optometrists and lawyers, and by a $3 charge on state employers for each worker. Jessica Bruder
docs.abstract: Gov James McGreevey signs legislation to provide $78 million in aid for doctors facing steep increases in malpractice insurance premiums; bill would not cap pain and suffering awards (S)
docs.snippet: Governor McGreevey has signed legislation that will provide $78 million in aid for doctors facing steep increases in malpractice insurance premiums. But the bill does not include the provision that insurers and the New Jersey Medical Society wanted...

docs.lead_paragraph: BY many measures, today's older workers appear better equipped for retirement than any previous generation. Their homes are worth more than their parents' homes were. Their bank accounts are fatter. And study after study suggests that typical late-middle-age employees have accumulated more wealth than their counterparts did a quarter-century ago. But virtually all of these studies have a flaw, a crucial asset that is left out of the equation. Add it back in, and the rosy picture suddenly darkens.

headline.main: Healthier and Wiser? Sure, but Not Wealthier

docs.abstract: Studies showing today's older workers are better prepared for retirement than previous generations fail to take into account demise of tradition pension, employee benefit widely available until early 1980's; fewer than half of households headed by people 47 to 64 had someone earning pension in 2001, down from over two-thirds in 1983; impact of shift on family finances has gotten little attention because it is hard to measure; new evidence suggests waning of pension has stripped older workers of immense store of wealth; near-retirees in typical households are a little poorer, in constant dollars, than previous generation when it neared retirement in 1983; pension plans served as social leveler in past, while advent of self-directed retirement plans is giving rise to elite minority who are well prepared for retirement and majority who are falling behind; household net worth graph; photos (M)
docs.snippet: BY many measures, today's older workers appear better equipped for retirement than any previous generation. Their homes are worth more than their parents' homes were. Their bank accounts are fatter. And study after study suggests that typical...

byline.original: By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH; J. Alex Tarquinio contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Three big insurance companies, Aetna, Cigna and MetLife, said yesterday that they had received subpoenas from the New York attorney general as an investigation widened into the field of employee benefits -- health, disability and group life insurance. Hartford, which operates a substantial business in group life and disability insurance as well as in commercial and personal lines of insurance, said late Thursday that it, too, had received a subpoena.

headline.main: Spitzer Inquiry Expands to Employee-Benefits Insurance

docs.abstract: Three big insurance companies, Aetna, Cigna and MetLife, say they received subpoenas from New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer as investigation widens into field of employee benefits--health, disability and group life insurance; Hartford, which operates substantial business in group life and disability insurance as well as in commercial and personal lines of insurance, says that it, too, received subpoena (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: According to ''Drug Discount Confusion'' (editorial, June 2), the Bush administration needs to help the elderly understand and sign up for drug discount cards. I don't think this is possible since I don't think anyone in the administration or in Medicare fully understands this program. I am an educated, highly intelligent 65-year-old who has tried to unravel the mystery of this program, and I have yet to make sense of it. A neighbor and I both called Medicare and got different answers to the same questions.
docs.abstract: Janice L Winchester letter responds to June 2 editorial; expresses doubt that anyone in Bush administration or in Medicare fully understands drug discount card program

docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to slow the rising cost of providing health coverage, 50 of the country's largest employers are creating a buyers' club to bargain directly with drug makers on behalf of five million active and retired employees and their families. The move is a major departure from the current industry practice of employers paying middlemen -- known as pharmacy benefit management companies -- to provide drug coverage for their insured workers. Those prices are supposed to be at discounted rates. But because drug pricing is notoriously opaque, employers cannot be sure they are getting the best possible deal.

headline.main: Big Employers Join Forces in Effort to Negotiate Lower Drug Prices

docs.abstract: Fifty of country's largest employers are creating buyers' club to bargain directly with drug makers on behalf of five million active and retired employees and their families; move is major departure from current industry practice of employers paying middlemen--known as pharmacy benefit management companies--to provide drug coverage for their insured workers; those prices are supposed to be at discounted rates; but because drug pricing is notoriously opaque, employers cannot be sure if they are getting best possible deal; photos; chart (L)
